entries.def-search: a be call called give name nominate oneself to

senses.comment: In PF, this verb used to take a double accusative, but this usage disappeared early on in UF, with the second accusative, denoting the name, naturally being replaced by the absolutive, likely to avoid ambiguity that was starting to manifest as a result of UF’s increasingly free word order.
senses.def: +acc and abs To call, name, nominate, give a name to.

examples.comment: Even in the writings of <f-s>Snet’h</f-s>, the double accusative is no longer attested.
examples.text: <f-s>Snet’h v.2</f-s> <f-w>jdap rác’hsaý’adâ</f-w> ‘I call you a liar’.

def.def: +<f-s>subj</f-s> So that, so as to, to, in order to.

entries.def-search: as in order so that to

senses.comment:
Exclusively used in the passive of the weather or a situation or state of affairs, with the noun for the condition or preciptation as the ‘object’ and no subject (see examples below).

In Middle UF, fér with a noun in the abs was often used for this purpose, hence also the irregular fut and subj, e.g. *sfér cẹaû ‘It is hot’; similarly, weather conditions used to be their own verbs, e.g. *slýv́á ‘it rains’.

The latter were eventually replaced with a construction using b’hér in the passive with the noun in the part, e.g. *dŷnḷẹ syb’hér ‘it rains’ (lit. ‘some rain is being poured’). This was later extended to any state (of the weather), e.g. dŷncẹaû syb’hér (lit. ‘some heat is being poured’). The acc can be used instead as an intensifier, e.g. sc̣ẹaû syb’hér ‘it is scorching hot’.

With precipitation, the pl is most common in modern times, e.g. dýḷẹ syb’hér instead of older *dŷnḷẹ syb’hér. The old weather verbs, e.g. *lýv́á, are altogether obsolete.
senses.def: pass + part/acc (of a state or condition) to obtain; (of precipitation) to fall.

examples.text: <f-w>dýḷẹ syb’hér</f-w> ‘it rains’.
<f-w>dŷncẹaû syb’hér</f-w> ‘it is hot’.
<f-w>dyraúvá léâ syb’hér</f-w> ‘it’s a full moon’.

entries.etym: from <f-pf>vérité</f-pf>; the /i/ disappeared during Early Middle UF

senses.comment: Literally ‘how much time’. This is generally used with either the present or future tense. The present tense is used when the focus is how long ago an ongoing event started in the past, and the future tense when discussing how far it will extend into the future.

senses.comment: Requires a negative context and thus frequently appears as ní’sý’ýâ. If there is no verb, the negation may be ommitted. Often paired with another ní or preceding negated clause, in which case ní generally replaces the negation particle of the later clause.
Unlike au and u/ra, this conjunction is postpositive and usually appears in the same position as particles rather than before the things it joins.

examples.text: <f-w>Aý’èc’hsád j(v)nvé</f-w> ‘My name is Aý’èc’hsád’.

examples.comment: While <f-w>-c’h’s</f-w> for <f-w>c’hes</f-w> is archaic nowadays, this is a set phrase that preserves this form. Because this renders this phrase rather recognisable, the <f-w>a</f-w> is often dropped in informal speech. Note also that this is a passive, with the plural being <f-w>A b’hýnvẹ́ c’hes</f-w>.
examples.text: <f-w>(A) ḍẹnvẹ́c’h’s ?</f-w> ’What’s your name?’, lit. ‘What are you called?’.

def.def: To reduce (+acc or pass. sbd./sth.) (+all to sth.).

def.comment: Both réhyý’ and rêt’hé can mean ‘far’, but they differ in perspective: réhyý’ is used to describe a great distance or the crossing of one, whereas rêt’hé is used to describe something far away.

examples.text: <f-w>Jráy’áé réhyý’vâ.</f-w> ‘I have travelled far.’
<f-w>Jráy’áé ádŷnḅéy’í rêt’hê.</f-w> ‘I travelled to a distant land.’
<f-w>disḍas réhyý’â</f-w> ‘a great distance’.

def.comment: For ‘thinking’ in the sense of ‘thinking about something’ rather than ‘thinking that something is the case’, see c’hóhid’hẹ́.

The acc is generally preferred, but in cases where it is either questionable who discovered something first, or whether something is ‘discovered’ as opposed to ‘invented’, the part may be used instead.
Exclamation of distress, surprise, sadness, or regret.

entries.forms: after words that end with ‘r’, this is spelt -vá instead

entries.def-search: be completed completeto comprehensive exhaustive finished to

def.comment: Always enclitic s’ before vowels. This particle is used only in the subjunctive; see also asý’ýâ, t’hé.
Never lenited.

entries.def-search: form kind kinds of some sort type

def.comment: The case depends on the depth of the speaker’s understanding: the acc indicates ‘complete’ or expert-level understanding, the part only some understanding. In questions, the acc is rather harsh (similar to ‘do you have even the slightest idea ...’) with the part preferred if a more neutral tone is intended. In negated statements, the acc indicates a complete lack of understanding (‘I have no idea whatsoever ...’), whereas the part is again neutral.

intr. (archaic) Same as 2, but implicitly reflexive even though it is morphologically only intransitive. This sense has been largely replaced by the morphological reflexive.

def.comment: Precedes and is attached to nouns; often sý’ before vowels, with one apostrophe, not two.

senses.comment: This is both an adjective verb and an adjective: the adjective form is always sýr, not *sýrâ, but it can also be conjugated, e.g. jsýr ‘I am sure’.

def.comment: Always t’h’N before vowels, but does not nasalise if the ‘é’ is still present. This particle is used only in the optative; see also asý’ýâ, sá.
Only T’hebhaú is declined as though the entire phrase were one word. In informal speech and writing, this is typically shortened to Raúl.

senses.comment: Inclusive, see also ra.

entries.def-search: able be can capable may might of possible to

senses.comment: Never construed with an inf if it in and of itself is the infinitive of an aci or pci, in which case the variant with the part (2) is used instead.
Dynamic or epistemic, never deontic; this and sense 4 are essentially a more emphatic optative.
senses.def: <f-s>opt cond i + aci</f-s> To be possible; may.

senses.comment: Dynamic or epistemic, never deontic.

senses.comment: In this sense, vêvâ usually precedes the noun (phrase) it qualifies.

examples.text: <f-s>H. P. Lovecraft:</f-s> <f-w>Lavúrer’sý’ýâ là dwájávé sdaúr / Ádȅr trâ vêvâ Dérny’éhuf laúv’raú.</f-w> ‘That is not dead which can eternal lie / And with strange æons even death may die’.
